summary: This is a 2019 federal court opinion and order (Case No. 08-80736-CIV-MARRA) addressing motions in a civil case brought by Jane Doe 1 and Jane Doe 2 against the United States. The document details the background of the Jeffrey Epstein investigation, the secret negotiation and execution of a 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) between the U.S. Attorney's Office and Epstein's lawyers, and the government's alleged violations of the Crime Victims' Rights Act by failing to consult with victims. This document is part of a court filing (likely a motion for summary judgment or related pleading) detailing the timeline of events and communications surrounding the 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) between Jeffrey Epstein and the U.S. Attorney's Office. It focuses on disputes over victim notification under the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA), revealing efforts by Epstein's defense team to delay or limit notifications and internal government communications about legal obligations. This is a court order from a civil case (Case 9:08-cv-80736-KAM) granting partial summary judgment to Jane Doe 1 and Jane Doe 2. The court finds the U.S. Government violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA) by entering into a Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) with Jeffrey Epstein without conferring with the victims. The order discusses the legal standards for summary judgment and the scope of victims' rights under the CVRA.

events.title: Palm Beach Police Complaint
events.description: The Town of Palm Beach Police Department received a complaint from parents about the sexual abuse of their 14-year-old daughter by Jeffrey Epstein, leading to the identification of approximately 20 minor victims.

events.title: FBI Investigation Opened
events.description: At the request of the Palm Beach Police, the FBI opened an investigation into allegations that Epstein and his assistants used interstate commerce to induce minors into illegal sexual activities.

events.title: Jane Doe 1 Provides Information to FBI
events.description: Jane Doe 1 provided information to the FBI about her abuse and the abuse of Jane Doe 2 by Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Secret NPA Negotiations
events.description: Extended negotiations took place between the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida and Jeffrey Epstein's attorneys, culminating in a secret Non-Prosecution Agreement.

events.title: Draft Indictment and Memo Prepared
events.description: By May 2007, the U.S. Attorney's Office had drafted an 82-page prosecution memorandum and a 53-page indictment outlining numerous federal sexual offenses committed by Epstein.

events.title: Non-Prosecution Agreement Executed
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein and the U.S. Attorney's Office formally entered into a Non-Prosecution Agreement, deferring federal prosecution in favor of state prosecution and granting immunity to Epstein and potential co-conspirators.

events.title: FBI Agents Meet Jane Doe 1
events.description: FBI Special Agents, including Jason Richards, met with Jane Doe 1 to explain Epstein's guilty plea to state charges but allegedly did not disclose that the NPA had already been signed.

events.title: Government Sends Draft Victim Notification
events.description: The Government sent an email to Epstein's attorney Lefkowitz attaching a draft victim notification letter dated for the next day, explaining the NPA terms.

events.title: Lefkowitz Objects to Victim Notification
events.description: Epstein's attorney Lefkowitz sent a letter to U.S. Attorney Acosta objecting to sending victim notification letters before Epstein's plea or sentencing.

events.title: Stan Objects to Victim Notification
events.description: Epstein's attorney Kenneth Stan sent a letter to U.S. Attorney Acosta objecting to the victim notification letter and requesting review rights.

events.title: Sanchez Requests Notification Hold
events.description: Defense attorney Lilly Ann Sanchez sent a letter requesting the U.S. Attorney's Office hold off on sending any victim notification letters.

events.title: FBI Sends Misleading Letters to Victims
events.description: The FBI sent letters to Jane Doe 1 and Jane Doe 2 stating the case was 'under investigation,' not disclosing the existence of the NPA.

events.title: Jane Doe 1 Meets with FBI and AUSA
events.description: Jane Doe 1 met with FBI Agents and an AUSA, providing details of abuse, but was not told about the already-negotiated NPA.

events.title: Epstein Pleads Guilty in State Court
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein pled guilty to state law solicitation of prostitution charges, resolving the federal investigation per the NPA.

events.title: Jane Doe 1 Files Emergency CVRA Petition
events.description: Jane Doe 1 filed an emergency petition for enforcement of her rights under the Crime Victims' Rights Act.

events.title: Victim Notification Letters Finally Sent
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office sent victim notification letters to Jane Doe 1, Jane Doe 5, and other identified victims, explaining some NPA provisions.

events.title: Motion to Release NPA Filed
events.description: Jane Doe 1 and Jane Doe 2 filed a motion seeking release of the Non-Prosecution Agreement.

events.title: Government sends letters to victims
events.description: The U.S. Government sent letters to the victims (including Jane Doe 1 and 2) counseling 'patience' with the investigation, even after it had already entered into the NPA with Epstein.

events.title: Jane Doe 2 identified as victim
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office sent Jane Doe 2 a CVRA letter, indicating it considered her a victim at that time.

events.title: Court grants partial summary judgment on CVRA violation
events.description: Judge Kenneth A. Marra issues an order granting Jane Doe 1 and Jane Doe 2's motion for partial summary judgment, finding the Government violated their right to conferral under the CVRA by entering into the NPA with Epstein without notifying them.

West Palm Beach, Palm Beach County, Florida
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein sexually abused more than 30 minor girls between 1999 and 2007, and used paid employees to find and bring minors to him.

A secret Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) was negotiated and signed on September 24, 2007, between the U.S. Attorney's Office and Epstein's lawyers, granting Epstein and potential co-conspirators immunity from federal prosecution.

The U.S. Attorney's Office deliberately kept the NPA secret from the victims, did not consult with them before signing it, and negotiated with Epstein's defense about what to tell the victims, violating standard practice and the Crime Victims' Rights Act.
The NPA contained a provision that it would not be made part of any public record and that the government would notify Epstein before disclosing it in response to a FOIA request.
Epstein's defense team, particularly attorney Jay Lefkowitz, actively sought to control communications to victims and prevent the NPA from becoming public.
Epstein's defense attorneys repeatedly objected to and sought to delay victim notification letters required by the Justice for All Act of 2004 (CVRA).

The U.S. Attorney's Office, under Alexander Acosta, delayed victim notifications at the defense's request and sent misleading letters to victims stating investigations were ongoing after the NPA was signed.
Victims, including Jane Doe 1, were not informed of the NPA's existence during meetings with the FBI and AUSA in early 2008, despite the agreement having been finalized in September 2007.
The government's draft victim notification letter stated the FBI and U.S. Attorney's Office would 'decline comment' if asked about the Non-Prosecution Agreement.
The document reveals internal government acknowledgment that they had proof beyond a reasonable doubt that identified individuals were victims of Epstein's criminal conduct while minors.

The court ruled the U.S. Government violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA) by entering into a Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) with Jeffrey Epstein without conferring with the victims, Jane Doe 1 and Jane Doe 2.

The Government concealed the existence of the NPA from the victims and misled them to believe federal prosecution was still possible, even sending letters asking for 'patience' after the agreement was signed.

The court rejected the Government's argument that Jane Doe 2 was not a protected victim under the CVRA because she made early statements favorable to Epstein, noting there was no dispute Epstein sexually abused her while she was a minor.
The court's ruling is on the liability issue (the CVRA violation) only; the remedy for the violation is to be determined in a subsequent proceeding.
The document references that the NPA negotiations included repeated assurances from the Government to Epstein's attorneys that the agreement would not be 'made public or filed with the Court.'
